Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 08:01AM smerf wrote: My DH had surgery twice for discs, so he did at first think it could be that again. The pain started on a Friday afternoon, and the next morning he started running a low grade fever, and feeling nauseated. That's when I told him it seemed more like a stone, because I have seen it before. Long ago I was working on a urology unit, when I first became an RN. It can be serious, as obstruction can cause sepsis and kidney damage. If you went to the ER in terrible pain, would they not do a workup to at least get the dx? My husband was diagnosed in the ER with the u/a and CT. He was given Toradol IV, which works very well for stone pain, and got almost immediate relief. He had a lithotripsy yhat Monday to break up the stone, and then it was passed over the next week or so.
Posts.Title: Kidneys? barbe1958 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 09:28AM smerf wrote: Your post just caught my eye because i'm interested in all things kidney. I was just going to post something suggesting stones when your last post popped up! I'm so glad you found out what the problem is, just wish you didn't have to wait for tx. The same pain you described happened to my DH a few years ago, but he thought it was another slipped disc, as he has that history. I wanted to take him to ER, but he was too stubborn, of course, he's a man, after all. 36 hours of agony later, he let me take him in, and the doctor there immediately ordered a urinanalysis which showed micrscopic red blood cells. That sent him for CT which showed huge, 8mm kidney stone. He has had no further trouble since his lithotripsy, but has to drink lots of water to prevent another stone. Best to you, and may you soon be pain free!
Posts.Title: Kidneys? barbe1958 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 06:50AM smerf wrote: Hi Debi, Yes, I too had the toenails, and fingersnails too turning color and developing ridges. Also the nosebleeds, headaches, body aches, and neuropathy, mostly in the feet. Now two years later I feel very good, but I still do have some residual neuropathy in my feet. It took a long time for my nails too improve, about a year. Try to be patient, because the improvement is gradual, but you will get there. I had twelve weekly taxols, and in spite of the se's it was easier than the 4 ac txs I had first. Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: feeling lonely,nervous,anxiety ridden auntiekayro GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 10:04AM smerf wrote: My surgeon was doing sentinel node biopsies for melanoma before breast, which I thought was interesting. I hope they find yet more uses for it in the future. Beesie, I see that you are in Canada, and maybe we do biopsies differently here? Lab techs do run tests, such as pap smears, bloodwork, urines, and others, but pathologists who are MD's do the biopsies. They look at the slides, determine what they show, and then dictate the report. Sometimes they also speak to our doctors, but they almost never talk to patients. Mostly, they would not be the appropriate one because they are not treating us, and not prepared to discuss treament of any kind. So I guess that could be frustrating to some, but maybe for the best because we would then have to wait to talk to our oncologists about tx, and waiting is sometimes the hardest part!
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 09:04AM smerf wrote: Absolutely agree with you, Beesie. Except that radiologists are doctors, and often can explain our mammograms to us. Radiology techs are not supposed to interpret our films, but sometimes they try anyway.
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 04:18PM smerf wrote: We are more likely to bleed during chemo which affects out blood cells in many ways, including decreased platelets. Chemo also affects all the fast growing cells, like hair and skin, so we could have a GI bleed, or bleeding gums etc. Tylenol is usually okay for pain, but if we get a fever more than 101.4, or what ever your own onc says, then they usually want us to call before taking Tylenol. The reason is that, depending on your circumstances such as other symptoms, they might want you to have blood drawn for cultures. I'm finished with chemo since August of 2006, and I'm back on aspirin as a preventative for stroke or heart attack. Glad if it also helps prevent recurrence! Hope this helps. Sometimes I feel like my chemo brain makes me incoherent.
Posts.Title: aspirin mpieterse mpieterse

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 08:58AM smerf wrote: My ten boosts took a little longer than my regular txs, but the break to the rest of my burned skin was very welcome! It's all individual, based on your specific tumor, and in my case they used IMRT for the boosts, while it was 3D conformal for the whole breast. In any case, congrats to you, you are almost finished!
Posts.Title: boosts?? zschweeb zschweeb

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 04:15PM smerf wrote: My tumor was right on the chest wall, and the surgeon couldn't take any more tissue. In fact, so close that the surgeon removed the fascia that lies between the breast and the chest wall. I did not have a mastectomy because the recommendation would still be to do radiation. I had six months of chemo first, then seven weeks of rads with the last ten being boosts to the tumor area. I did a lot of research first because I was willing to have more surgery if it meant skipping rads, but I eventually realized doing the rads was the most agressive tx in my situation. I finished at the end of October in 06, and so far so good.

Posts.Title: B-9 Results! CKCSLover hollyann

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 03:23PM smerf wrote: Hi Mary, We have the same size tumor, and both triple negs. At first onc visit we went through a detailed medical hx, and talked in detail about the path report. A physical exam is done, and onc will discuss which chemo drugs she/he would use. She went over the names with me, and exactly how each one attacks cancer cells. Talked about side effects too, and how to handle them. She also told me my prognosis in statistics with and without chemo. For triple negs there isn't much choice...we need, and respond well to chemo. My onc wanted me to have a muga scan for the heart, and a bone scan, so she gave me those orderes, along with an order for a "cranial prosthesis", which is, of course, the wig. Insurance requires the order to be written, and my insurance reimbursed 70% of cost. Muga scan needed if adriamycin is indicated in chemo mix. I had four txs of ac every three weeks, followed by twelve weekly taxols. My tumor was on the chest wall, so I had 7 weeks of radiation after chemo. Would still have needed rads with a mastectomy, though shorter duration. Had my three year "cancerversary" last Feb, and doing well, and you will too! I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: First ONC visit- what to expect? TexasRose TexasRose

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 12:29AM smerf wrote: Thanks Mary and Lainey. There was a time I thought I'd never get here, but I did, and so will you guys. I'll be rooting for you all the way. Caroline has a good idea about the notebook and questions. Jot down things you want to ask, and bring the list to your appointment. Most oncs will also give you some written material about se's and such. They know there is a lot to remember. I am an RN, and so I did sometimes care for people with cancer, and my Mom had bc, so I was pretty familiar with the routine. My DH always came with me, and he had questions though he is a physician himself. He does orthopedic surgery, not cancer care. I met with two oncologists just to get their opinions. They check heart and lungs, and do a detailed breast and node check. They also usually tap on the spine all the way down, checking for tender spots. They would check any other body parts where you might have issues gleaned from the history. I now feel like more people have seen my boobs than if I starred in x rated movies! I ended up choosing the oncologist who wanted to do the most agressive tx, and her reason was the "large tumor size." The first onc said three months of chemo, using two drugs. She wanted to do six months of chemo, using three different drugs. When I asked why, she responded the above, so I went with that. She also commented that it was the tx she would want in my shoes. I did not have a Pet scan, nor any CT scans because of the lack of lymph or vascular invasion. I feel like I'm rambling, so I hope this makes sense to you. Come back and tell us how your visit goes. We are all here, wishing you well.
Posts.Title: First ONC visit- what to expect? TexasRose TexasRose

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 03:40PM smerf wrote: Hi Marcella, I just saw your post and see that you are in Glenview too. I agree with everyone above that waiting is the hardest part. I hope that by now you have seen your surgeon, and that you have a plan. Pathologists don't do biopsies, but radiologists can. Pathologists examine the tissue after the biopsy, but you always need a surgeon to evaluate all the findings, including a breast exam, and then advise you as to what he/she feels should be done. You are young, and it is correct that 80% of biopsies are negative so don't worry unless you have to. You odds are very good, and I'm hoping for the best for you. Please let us know when you can. We are here for you.

Posts.Title: verrrry low white count marye Carolina59

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 12:37PM smerf wrote: I had a similar situation, with a 1mm margin at the chest wall. For various reasons, not my choice, I ended up having a lumpectomy rather than a mx. I wanted the most agressive tx after surgery, and had 4AC followed by twelve weekly taxols. First onc I consulted only wanted to do the AC because I had negative nodes. Second onc consult wanted to add the taxol because she considered my tumor to be "large" and wanted more insurance against recurrence. This onc also felt that because of the narrow margins, it would be most prudent to go ahead with rads no matter which surgery I had. The chest wall margin would have been too little even if I had a mx. Now I have just passed my 4 year mark, and I'm doing great. It was a lot of tx, but I wanted to know I had done everything possible, and rads were much easier than chemo. I did get some burn, but healed quickly when rads were finished. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2009 03:11PM smerf wrote: Hi Analemma, It's really important to find out about your DH's plan at work. Many plans won't cover you when you reach age 65, and if they do there is an increase in cost. They may have a good supplement to offer you at that point, if you have to switch to Medicare. Caryn, I think Annie is correct about having no lapse in coverage, but you have to have your DH check it out. Large group policies for employees and dependents often don't deny for pre-existings because they have large pools of members that balance them out. My DH is self employed, so we have had individual policies. It was a big financial relief to have him on Medicare, and he is so looking forward to having a Medicare wife!

Posts.Title: YIKES!! Lifetime insurance limit CarynRose lookingforward4more

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2009 01:04PM smerf wrote: Hi Caryn Rose, I'm so sorry you are having this problem. Last thing you need is more stress. I am aware that I have a lifetime limit on my insurance, but I will be 64 in May, so one more year before Medicare for me. I've been lucky so far, and finished tx in 2006. My DH can't wait for me to have Medicare, because my insurance is so expensive!  If you qualify for Medicare, they pay 80%, and then you need a supplement which you buy separately, and that pays the other 20%. My DH is 71, and has been on Medicare since he was 65. The supplement is much less expensive than other policies have been, and they don't refuse you for pre-existings as far as I know. Make sure you look at different policies, because some are better that others. There are some like HMO's, which are not as good as others. Give them a call, and I hope they can help you. Best of luck, Pat
Posts.Title: YIKES!! Lifetime insurance limit CarynRose lookingforward4more

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 05:28PM smerf wrote: Hi Daisyhope, Wishing you a good morning, and sending a hug your way. I want to say too, that this is all doable. People drive to their own chemo and rads treatments all the time. Hospital won't let you drive after surgery, and possibly local American Cancer Society could help. Aso, the hospital social workers may have ideas, or even your surgeon's office. Some hospitals have transportation services because many people can't drive to tests and procedures. A little investigation will probably bring a solution. Otherwise, remember you are not alone in this as long as we are here on this board! You are right about the stages we go through at DX. We've all been there, and you can come here to vent any time. We get it, and there are always women here ready with wonderful words of support and caring. Hang in there, you can do it! Pat

Posts.Title: tired, tired, tired motherof5 MJLToday

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 01:54PM smerf wrote: This can be confusing, because it varies from place to place, and insurance plan. That said, we are always entitled to a copy of the actual report rather than just the routine letter. Many places do not offer it, but will give it to you when you ask for it. It's a good idea to do that. Radiologists are MDs, and they can do some biopsies, or a surgeon can do it. The pathologist, also an MD, determines whether the tissue is benign or not. he then sends his report to the radiologist or surgeon, whoever did the biopsy. Often the docs share reports with our other doctors, such as gyn or pcp. It's a good idea for us to request a copy of the path report too, whatever it says. Surgeons always look at the films themselves, and never would go by just the radiology report. That is the only addition I have to what Otter said, and she gave a very good summary of a confusing process. In the age of digital mammos, my surgeon pulls up my films on the computer in her office, and goes over them with me. If you are still concerned after you talk to the radiologist, a consultation with a surgeon would be the next step if your insurance allows that. If not, and your gyn ordered the mammo, then you could ask him or her for a referral to a surgeon. It's worth it to have peace of mind. Best to you, smerf
Posts.Title: blonde question....very confused kunstnik kunstnik

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 11:02AM smerf wrote: Our payments for my DH's Medicare are very similar to NYCarol's. And, boy do I agree with her about not wanting the president to change Medicare! Right now you do not have to have a primary's referral to see a specialist, and that is wonderful. DH had to apply about 3 months in advance, and Medicare kicked in on the first day of his birthday month. It happens to be Dec 24th, so Medicare started Dec 1st. He did get a letter from his insurance company reminding him that he needed to apply, because they would not be covering him after 65. Don't know if they all do that. Read the fine print on the supplement, so that you get the best one for your needs. There are so many drug plans available, and it was so hard to go through them, so we asked our pharmacist which one to go with, and took his advice.
